Award.AwardTitle: Study of the Dynamics and Properties of Hot and Dense Quark and Gluon Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is a well-established fact that protons and neutrons are made up of smaller constituents called quarks and gluons. In collisions using two beams of heavy nuclei, a new state of matter is formed from these constituents, called the quark-gluon plasma (QGP). This project will answer fundamental questions about the QGP, such as the space-time dynamics of the QGP and its transport properties. The project will be carried out by studying the collective flow of fluctuations and particle interactions with the QGP. Studies of high energy density matter can have a profound impact on our understanding of the theory of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), which governs the behavior of nuclei and the evolution of the early universe, supernova explosions and the properties of neutron stars. The research will be carried out at the Large Hadron Collider in Europe using the ATLAS detector, and at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider of Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) using the STAR detector, with an emphasis on the Beam Energy Scan at BNL. Both the ATLAS and STAR experiments provide excellent training opportunities for graduate students.

The proposed measurements include: 1. Comprehensive model studies of particle correlations in transverse and longitudinal directions as compared with measurements to constrain the dynamics and properties of the matter in A+A collisions. This effort requires inventing new analysis methods, developing event-shape triggers to take advantage of the upcoming high-luminosity Pb+Pb run, as well as carrying out similar analyses at lower collision energy at RHIC. 2. Detailed efforts to map out the QCD phase diagram and search for the possible QCD critical point, by utilizing the higher-order cumulants of multiplicity and conserved charges in the STAR beam energy scan phase II program. The proposed efforts are built upon the group's established expertise in various correlation measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have performed several measurements that improved our understanding of  the dynamics, properties and phase structures of the high energy density matter, quark-gluon plasma (QGP), created in relativistic heavy-ion collisions at RHIC and the LHC. Specifically, through measurement of  collective flow fluctuations in both the transverse and the longitudinal directions, we probe the space-time dynamics of the matter and its transport properties. This include a precision measurement of longitudinal flow decorrelation in Xe+Xe and Pb+Pb collisions which was published in the Phys. Rev. Letts, and a comprehensive measurement of flow fluctuations in Pb+Pb collisions published in the Phys. Rev. C. In addition, we have carried out several model studies that either proposed new experimental observables or provided interpretation of the experimental measurements. These outcomes are important step toward achieving a more quantitative understanding of the microscopic mechanisms for the collective flow from small to large systems, and structures of the QCD phase diagram. The PI also served important leadership role in both STAR and ATLAS collaboration. Most noticeably, he has proposed a short O+O run to clarify the origin of collectivity in small collision systems and to disentangle the contributions from initial-state gluon saturation and final-state hydrodynamic collectivity. This RUN was successfully carried out in May 2021, taking more than 500M minimum bias and 200 M 0-5% central O+O events.

Studies of high energy density matter can have a profound impact on our understanding of QCD theory, the evolution of the early universe, and strongly interacting many-body system in general.  The experimental measurements of collectivity from small to large systems have inspired important new developments in string theories. The study of the nuclear deformation and QCD phase structures could provide important insights on the properties of neutron stars and mergers. Both the ATLAS and STAR experiments provide excellent training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, middle and high school students. Extensive education and outreach activities for middle and high school students in various formats will be offered. The PI is committed to attracting undergraduate and graduate students and providing them first rate training experience in fundamental nuclear science.
